name: transport, freight, sea, ferry | transport, freight, sea, ferry | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21323/documentation

The dataset represents the transport of one tonne of freight by a ferry over one kilometer. The DWT (load capacity) of the ferry is 1,200 tonnes, and it is estimated to transport an average of 140 million tonne.kms per year for 25 years (the average DWT and annual kilometres are weighted averages over the size class from data in IMO (2015)).;The dataset represents the entire transport life cycle including the production and maintenance of the ferry, the transportation of freight in bulk, and the construction of the port. The scope of this dataset is the operation of the ferry, which has inputs of the ship, maintenance and port facilities (i.e. ship production, ship mainenance and port construction inputs and emissions are contained in linked datasets).;Fuel consumption and the main emissions (CO2, NOx, SOx, PM, NMVOC, CO, CH4, N2O) are calculated as weighted averages over size classes from IMO (2015). Emisisons at sea, emissions in controlled areas (ECA) and emissions in ports from the main engine, auxiliary engine and boiler are considered. Weighted averages of speed reduction (36%) and capacity utilsation factors (50%) from IMO (2015) are applied (the capacity utilisation factors take into account both the cargo load factor and an empty trip factor). The share of trip length and port time inside emssion controlled areas (ECAs) (where other fuel quality is used) are estimated to 5% and 50% respectively. ;Emissions other than those listed above are calculated based on emission factors per kg fuel consumed from ecoinvent v2 (Spielmann et al., 2007). Emissions of xylene, toluene and benzene are no longer split out from non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOCs) in the datset as the method used by Spielmann et al. (2007) is considered too approximate (based on hydrocarbon emissions from road vehicles).;Port facilities have not been updated are representative of a single large port (Rotterdam). One common port facility is assumed for all commodities and ship types. Vessel production and maintenance are global in scope and described in the individual datsets.;References: ;IMO (2015) Third IMO Greenhouse Gas Study 2014. International Maritime Organization, London;Spielmann et al (2007) Transport services. ecoinvent Report No. 14. Villigen

The scope of this dataset is the operation of the ferry, with the production and maintenance of the ferry and port facilities contained in linked datasets. The transportation service starts with demand for construction of a ferry and the consumption of fuel (and associated emissions). 

The dataset ends with the service of transporting 1 tonne over a distance of 1 km. The dataset includes the operation of an average ferry and links to the production and maintenance of one ship and the construction of one port. Use of main engine, auxiliary engine and boiler is covered both at sea, in emission controlled areas and in port. The dataset includes the consumption of fuel, airborne gaseous emissions, particulate emissions, heavy metal emissions, persistent organic compounds (POPs) emissions, antifouling emissions to water and the disposal of bilge oil.
category: H:Transportation and storage/50:Water transport/501:Sea and coastal water transport/5012:Sea and coastal freight water transport

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Fuel consumption and emissions are calculated hourly covering the years 2007 to 2012
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: tonne*km is from weighted averages (global shipping data); infrastructure demand calculated using data from the largest port in Europe (Rotteradam)
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Fuel consumption and emissions are representative of the current technology (used in 2012 and considering the age distribution of global fleet). Load capacity (1,200 tonnes), fuel consumption and emissions are global weighted averages on tkms over the size classes from IMO (2015).
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Calculation of fuel consumption and emissions performed for each in-service ship during each hour of each year from 2007 to 2012 (data from IMO, 2015).

Reference: 
IMO (2015) Third IMO Greenhouse Gas Study 2014. International Maritime Organization, London

flow.name: transport, freight, sea, ferry
flow.category: H:Transportation and storage/50:Water transport/501:Sea and coastal water transport/5012:Sea and coastal freight water transport

exchanges.description: Calculated from emission factor per kg fuel consumption in IMO 2015. Reference: IMO (2015) Third IMO Greenhouse Gas Study 2014. International Maritime Organization, London

flow.name: Methane, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Extrapolated from ecoinvent v2 (Spielmann et al, 2007), applying an emission factor per kg fuel consumed. Reference: Spielmann et al (2007) Transport services. ecoinvent Report No. 14. Villigen. Comment in ecoinvent v2: Calculated value. The figures employed in this project represent a mix between the values for distilled and residual fuels (using a distilled/residual ratio of 28:72 according to IMO (2000)). Energy use and combustion emissions. Further references:
IMO (2000) Study of greenhouse gas emissions from ships.

exchanges.description: Unspecified hydrocarbons to water used as a proxy for paint to water during ship usage. Total paint to water  (less antifoul emissions) based on: Ship lightweight mass calculated from IHSF data, Papanikolaou (2014) data and Anink & Krikke (2011) data. Paint usage data estimated by Kameyama et al. (n.d.), Harish & Sunil (2014) and Nicolae et al. (2014). Paint emission data from OECD (2009). Average ship lifetime tonne-km calculated from IHSF data.

exchanges.description: Estimate, applying an emission factor of 0.005 kg bilge oil per kg fuel consumed, as in ecoinvent v2 (spielmann et al, 2007). Uncertainty range also from ecoinvent v2. Reference: Spielmann et al (2007) Transport services. ecoinvent Report No. 14. Villigen

exchanges.description: Extrapolated from ecoinvent v2 (Spielmann et al, 2007), applying an emission factor per kg fuel consumed. Reference: Spielmann et al (2007) Transport services. ecoinvent Report No. 14. Villigen. Comment in ecoinvent v2: Literature studies. Uncertainty range accounts for a factor between  1.25E-10 g/kg and 8E-09 g/kg. It's assumed an average value of 1ng/kg Dioxins, measured as 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin. defaultProvider.category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/38:Waste collection, treatment and disposal activities; materials recovery/382:Waste treatment and disposal/3822:Treatment and disposal of hazardous waste

exchanges.description: Total antifoul release based on Dutch environmental study (NNWB (2008)), assuming antifoul releases are the same for all ships. Average ship lifetime tonne-km calculated from IHSF data. Unspecified fungicides to ocean water used as a proxy to cover a number of fungicides and algicides used in antifoul paint and released into the ocean environment. These compounds are: dichlofluanid (fungicide), cybutryne (fungicide), tolylfluanid (fungicide), Sea-nine (algicide), zineb (fungicide) and zinc pyrithione (algicide). These compounds are released from ships in equal concentrations according to the Dutch environmental study (NNWB, 2008).

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Calculation uses the average days at sea, average dead weight and average speed (per ship type) (all from IMO 2014), port capacity based on Rotterdam (average total throughput 2010-2012) and an assumed port life time of 100 years.
